title: World Currencies
description: How well do you know the currencies of the world?

questions.question: What is the official currency of Japan?
questions.explanation: The Japanese yen (¥) has been the official currency of Japan since 1871. The word 'yen' means 'round object' in Japanese.

questions.question: Which country uses the currency called the 'baht'?
questions.explanation: The baht is the official currency of Thailand. One baht is divided into 100 satang.

questions.question: What is the official currency of the United Kingdom?
questions.explanation: The pound sterling (£) is the world's oldest currency still in use, dating back over 1,200 years.

questions.question: Which currency is used in India?
questions.explanation: The Indian rupee (₹) is the official currency of India. The word 'rupee' is derived from the Sanskrit word 'rupya,' meaning wrought silver.

questions.question: What currency do they use in Brazil?
questions.explanation: The Brazilian real (R$) was introduced in 1994 as part of a plan to stabilize the Brazilian economy. 'Real' means 'royal' in Portuguese.

questions.question: Which country uses the 'zloty' as its currency?
questions.explanation: The zloty (zł) is the official currency of Poland. The name literally means 'golden' in Polish.

questions.question: What is the official currency of South Africa?
questions.explanation: The South African rand (R) takes its name from the Witwatersrand, the ridge upon which Johannesburg is built and where most of South Africa's gold deposits were found.

questions.question: Which of these countries does NOT use the euro?
questions.explanation: Switzerland uses the Swiss franc (CHF), not the euro. Switzerland is not a member of the European Union and has maintained its own currency.

questions.question: What is the currency of Turkey?
questions.explanation: The Turkish lira (₺) is the currency of Turkey. The name 'lira' comes from the Latin word 'libra,' meaning pound.

questions.question: Which country uses the 'krona' as its currency?
questions.explanation: Sweden uses the krona (SEK). While Norway uses the krone and Denmark uses the krone as well, the specific spelling 'krona' is used by Sweden (and Iceland).

questions.question: What is the currency of South Korea?
questions.explanation: The South Korean won (₩) is the official currency of South Korea. The word 'won' is a cognate of the Chinese yuan and Japanese yen.

questions.question: Which currency is nicknamed the 'loonie'?
questions.explanation: The Canadian dollar is nicknamed the 'loonie' because the one-dollar coin features an image of a common loon, a bird found throughout Canada.

questions.question: What is the official currency of Vietnam?
questions.explanation: The Vietnamese dong (₫) is the currency of Vietnam. The word 'dong' comes from the Vietnamese term for the Chinese bronze coins used in ancient times.

questions.question: Which country uses the 'sol' as its currency?
questions.explanation: The sol is the currency of Peru. The name comes from the Latin word 'solidus' and also means 'sun' in Spanish, a reference to the Inca sun god Inti.

questions.question: What is the currency of Hungary?
questions.explanation: The Hungarian forint (Ft) is the currency of Hungary. The name comes from the city of Florence, Italy, where gold coins called 'fiorino d'oro' were minted in 1252.
